questions.q: What is the primary purpose of a computer network?
questions.explanation: The primary objective of a network is to let devices exchange information and share resources like hard drives and printers.
options: To increase the cost of communication
To enable devices to share resources and communicate

questions.q: Which of the following is a type of broadcast communication?
questions.explanation: Limited Broadcast is a form of broadcast transmission where data reaches all hosts in the same network.

questions.q: What does 'Multicast' refer to in networking?
questions.explanation: Multicast is a one-to-many transmission that sends data to a specific group of subscribed devices.

questions.q: Which technology allows people at distant locations to hold meetings?
questions.explanation: Videoconferencing allows people at distant locations to see and hear each other, eliminating travel costs and time.

questions.q: Which of the following is NOT a form of computer-assisted communication?
questions.explanation: Traditional mail is a manual process, unlike email or videoconferencing which utilize network infrastructure.

questions.q: What type of broadcast is characterized by sending data to all devices in a network?
questions.explanation: Broadcast (One-to-All) sends data to every device connected to the network.

questions.q: Which of the following statements is true regarding Limited Broadcast?
questions.explanation: In Limited Broadcast, data is sent from a source to all hosts within the same network.
options: It sends data to all devices in the network.
It sends data to a specific group of devices.
It is the same as Unicast.
It is not used in networking.

questions.q: In a computer network, which type of communication is most efficient for sending data to a single recipient?
questions.explanation: Unicast is a one-to-one transmission, making it the most efficient method for a single intended recipient.

questions.q: Which of the following best describes the term 'casting' in computer networks?
questions.explanation: Casting is defined as the method of transmitting data from a source to recipient(s) over a communication channel.
options: The process of creating a network
The method of transmitting data from a source to one or more recipients
The act of securing a network

questions.q: Which type of network is designed to cover a large geographical area, such as a city or country?
questions.explanation: Wide Area Networks (WAN) connect large geographical areas such as states, countries, or continents.

questions.q: If a network link fails, which of the following features ensures that communication can still occur?
questions.explanation: Redundancy provides high reliability by ensuring alternative routes or sources are available if a link or processor fails.

questions.q: In a multicast transmission, how is data delivered?
questions.explanation: Multicast specifically targets a group of devices that have subscribed to receive the transmission.
options: To all devices in the network
To a specific group of subscribed devices
To devices in a random manner

questions.q: Which of the following best describes a Local Area Network (LAN)?
questions.explanation: LANs are used to connect devices in limited areas like a home, school, or office, typically spanning up to 1 km.
options: A network that connects devices over long distances
A network that connects devices within a limited geographical area
A network that connects devices using satellite communication
A network that is only used for mobile devices

questions.q: What is the significance of network topology in computer networking?
questions.explanation: Network topology, also called network configuration, describes the shape or physical connectivity and layout of the network.
options: It determines the physical layout of the network
It defines the protocols used for communication
It specifies the types of devices that can be connected
It is irrelevant to network performance
